data.diagnosis:
Multiple gastric ulcers, nature to be determined by pathology.  
Barrett's esophagus C1M2.  
Hiatal hernia.
data.full_findings:
The mucosa of the upper and middle esophagus is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristalsis. A circumferential reddish-orange mucosa is observed above the dentate line in the lower esophagus, with a circumferential metaplastic mucosa length of C-1 cm and a maximum metaplastic mucosa length of M-2 cm.  
The cardia is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardiac orifice.  
The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices observed.  
In the anterior wall of the lower gastric body, there is a 1.0 cm × 1.0 cm A2-stage ulcer, Forrest classification III, oval in shape, with clear borders, congested and edematous base, covered with white exudate, and thickened surrounding mucosa. Two biopsies were taken, showing soft texture and easy bleeding. Another healing-stage ulcer measuring 0.3 × 0.3 cm is observed on the greater curvature of the gastric body.  
On the lesser curvature of the gastric angle, there is a 1.0 cm × 1.0 cm A2-stage ulcer, Forrest classification III, round in shape, with clear borders, congested and edematous base, covered with white exudate, and thickened surrounding mucosa. Two biopsies were taken, showing soft texture and easy bleeding.  
The gastric antrum mucosa is smooth, with a red and white appearance predominantly red, and good peristalsis.  
The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a round pyloric orifice and regular peristalsis.  
The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers.  
The mucosa of the descending duodenum shows no abnormalities.

Gastric Polypectomy
Chronic Atrophic Gastritis

data.diagnosis: Heterotopic gastric mucosa in the esophagus; Chronic non-atrophic gastritis.
data.full_findings:
Two island-like, round, orange-red ectopic mucosa patches are observed in the upper esophagus, with smooth surfaces and clear boundaries. The remaining esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristalsis. No significant tea-colored areas are noted under OE staining.  
The cardia is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardia opening.  
The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices.  
The gastric body mucosa is smooth, with distinct folds and good peristalsis.  
The gastric angle mucosa is smooth, showing a red and white pattern predominantly red.  
A mucosal elevation is observed on the lesser curvature of the gastric antrum, with redness at the apex. The remaining antral mucosa is congested and edematous, displaying a red and white pattern predominantly red, with good peristalsis.  
The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a round pyloric opening and regular peristalsis.  
The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers.  
The duodenal descending segment mucosa shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis:
Gastric cancer indocyanine green + titanium clip marking procedure
Chronic atrophic gastritis (C2)
data.full_findings:
The esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristalsis. No distinct brownish areas are observed under BLI.  
The gastroesophageal junction is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear Z-line and normal contraction of the cardia.  
The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices.  
In the lesser curvature of the gastric body, part of the mucosa shows a mottled appearance, while the remaining gastric body mucosa is edematous with clear folds and good peristalsis.  
The gastric angulus mucosa is congested and edematous, with a mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas.  
An irregularly shaped ulcer is observed on the lesser curvature of the gastric antrum, involving part of the anterior and posterior walls. The ulcer has clear borders, interrupted folds, an uneven base covered with dirty exudate, and irregularly elevated surrounding mucosa. Indocyanine green marking was performed in all four quadrants of the lesion, with one titanium clip placed on the oral side and one on the anal side. The remaining antral mucosa is smooth, with a mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas and good peristalsis.  
The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a rounded pyloric opening and regular peristalsis.  
The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers.  
The mucosa of the descending duodenum shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis:
Heterotopic gastric mucosa in the esophagus  
Chronic atrophic gastritis with verrucous elevation  
Gastric high-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (HGIN)
data.full_findings:
Two patchy areas of orange-red mucosa are observed at the esophageal entrance. The remaining mucosa appears smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristaltic contractions. No distinct brownish areas are noted under electronic chromoendoscopy.  

The gastroesophageal junction is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear Z-line and normal contraction of the cardia.  

The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices observed.  

The gastric body mucosa is smooth, with well-defined folds and good peristalsis.  

The gastric angulus mucosa shows congestion and edema, with a mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas.  

The gastric antrum mucosa exhibits congestion and edema, also presenting a mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas, with good peristalsis. On the anterior wall, lesser curvature, and posterior wall of the gastric antrum, a 0-IIc+IIa type lesion measuring approximately 3 cm × 2 cm and involving half the circumference is observed. The lesion mucosa appears erythematous with surface erosion. Under NBI and magnifying endoscopy: the lesion boundary is clear, with irregular microvasculature, papillary loop-pattern, irregular microstructure, visible white opaque substance (WOS), white globe appearance (WGA) in some areas, and light blue crest (LBC). Three biopsies were taken, showing soft texture and easy bleeding.  

The pyloric mucosa is congested and edematous, with a large verrucous elevation and surface erosion. The pyloric orifice is round, with regular peristalsis.  

The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers observed.  

The duodenal descending segment mucosa shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis:
Gastric angle mucosal lesion (suspected neoplastic change)  
Hiatal hernia  
Chronic atrophic gastritis with bile reflux; gastric xanthelasma
data.full_findings:
The esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clearly visible submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristaltic contractions.  
The gastroesophageal junction is located 36 cm from the incisors, with a clear squamocolumnar junction approximately 33 cm from the incisors. The cardia exhibits alternating contraction and relaxation, and two yellowish-white mucosal elevations with a granular surface are observed. Retroflexed view reveals the formation of a hiatal hernia sac.  
The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with yellowish staining in the mucus lake, and no varices are seen.  
In the posterior wall of the lower gastric body, one yellowish-white mucosal elevation with a granular surface is noted. The remaining gastric body mucosa is smooth, with distinct folds and good peristalsis.  
On the lesser curvature side of the gastric angle, a raised lesion measuring approximately 3.0 cm × 3.5 cm is observed. The surface is smooth, with slight central depression. One biopsy specimen was taken, which was soft in texture. The remaining gastric angle mucosa is smooth, showing a red and white mottled appearance, predominantly red.  
The gastric antrum mucosa exhibits congestion and edema, with a red and white mottled, patchy appearance, and good peristalsis.  
The pyloric mucosa is smooth, the pyloric orifice is round, and peristalsis is regular.  
The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers.  
The duodenal descending segment mucosa shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis:

Nature of gastric angle and pyloric mucosal lesions pending pathological examination
Chronic atrophic gastritis (C-2)
data.full_findings:
The gastroesophageal junction is located 42 cm from the incisors. A large protruding lesion is observed, involving approximately half of the circumference, with ulceration on the surface covered by thick white exudate. The lesion extends upward to the lower esophagus at 40 cm from the incisors and downward to the gastric cardia ridge. The cardia orifice shows relaxation and poor contraction. Six biopsies were taken from the lesion, which appeared friable and bled easily. The remaining esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristalsis. No distinct brownish areas are observed under NBI examination. The gastric fundus and body exhibit congested and edematous mucosa with scattered punctate erythema, clear folds, and good peristalsis.  

The gastric angulus shows congested and edematous mucosa with a rough, mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas. One biopsy was taken from the gastric angulus, which appeared soft.  

The gastric antrum displays congested and edematous mucosa with a mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas, and good peristalsis.  

The pylorus shows mucosal protrusion with surface congestion and edema. Two biopsies were taken from the pylorus, which appeared soft. The pyloric orifice is round with regular peristalsis.  

The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth without ulceration.  

The descending duodenum mucosa shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis:
Esophageal and gastric antrum submucosal elevation
Chronic atrophic gastritis (C-3)
Duodenal descending diverticulum
data.full_findings:
At 18 cm from the incisors, a submucosal elevation measuring approximately 0.3 × 0.3 cm is observed in the esophagus, with a smooth and slightly translucent surface mucosa. The remaining esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristaltic contractions. No distinct brownish areas are noted under electronic chromoendoscopy.  

The gastroesophageal junction is located at 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear Z-line and normal contraction of the cardia.  

The gastric fundus shows mucosal congestion and edema, with clear mucus lake and no varices.  

In the lower part of the gastric body, the mucosa along the greater curvature, anterior wall, and posterior wall appears thin and pale, with visible submucosal vascular patterns. The mucosa along the lesser curvature exhibits a mottled appearance. The remaining gastric body mucosa shows congestion and edema, with distinct folds, good peristalsis, and no visible regular arrangement of collecting venules (RAC).  

The gastric angulus mucosa is smooth, with a red-and-white mottled appearance, and no visible RAC.  

On the posterior wall of the gastric antrum, a submucosal elevation measuring approximately 0.6 × 0.8 cm is observed, with a central depression and a rough surface. Under CBI (magnifying endoscopy with blue laser imaging), the microvascular and microstructural patterns appear relatively regular. One biopsy specimen was taken. The remaining antral mucosa shows congestion and edema, with a red-and-white mottled appearance and good peristalsis.  

The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a rounded pyloric orifice and regular peristalsis.  

The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers.  

A diverticulum is observed in the descending part of the duodenum, with a smooth interior. The remaining mucosa of the descending duodenum shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis:
Esophageal variceal ligation
Gastric fundal variceal sclerotherapy
Cardiac mucosal tear
Portal hypertensive gastropathy
data.full_findings:
Four tortuous blue submucosal varices are observed in the lower esophagus, extending downward to the cardia, with positive red color signs. A spiral pattern of dense ligation was applied using a ligation device, starting from the cardia upward, with a total of 5 bands deployed.  
A longitudinal ulcer covered with white exudate is seen near the cardia adjacent to the gastric body, with no active bleeding.  
Multiple varices and varix clusters are noted in the gastric fundus, with the largest diameter measuring approximately 2.0 cm. A white thrombus head, approximately 0.6 cm in diameter, is visible. A total of 9 ml of tissue adhesive was injected using the hypertonic glucose sandwich method at multiple points, with intraoperative bleeding estimated at about 100 ml.  
The mucus pool is clear and moderate in volume. The gastric body mucosa shows congestion and edema. The gastric angle is arched, and the gastric antrum mucosa exhibits congestion and edema, appearing red and white with a predominance of redness.  
The pyloric orifice is round, smooth, and contracts well.  
The mucosa of the duodenal bulb and descending segment is smooth, with no abnormalities observed.

data.diagnosis:

Sclerotherapy for gastric fundal varices
data.full_findings:
At approximately 25 cm to 40 cm from the incisors, localized varices are observed in the esophagus, with a maximum diameter of 1.0 cm. Red color signs are negative, and no active bleeding is noted. Eleven bands were applied densely at the variceal site, and no bleeding was observed after the procedure.

The gastroesophageal junction is located at 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardia.

In the gastric fundus, ulceration due to glue detachment is observed, consistent with post-sclerotherapy changes for varices. The raised area feels firm upon biopsy forceps palpation, and newly developed varices are noted. One band was applied at the variceal site, and no bleeding was observed. The remaining mucosa shows congestion and edema, with clear mucus lake and no varices.

The gastric body mucosa exhibits congestion and edema, with clear folds and good peristalsis.

A patchy ulcer is observed on the greater curvature side, with fresh blood stains. Both ulcers were treated with argon plasma coagulation (APC), and three hemostatic clips were applied to the linear ulcer. The remaining anastomotic mucosa exhibits significant congestion and edema.  
The duodenal mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers observed.

data.diagnosis: Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) for achalasia
data.full_findings: The endoscope was inserted under conscious sedation. Upon entry, mild dilation of the esophageal body was observed, with reduced tension and tortuosity, along with retained fluid. After suctioning the retained fluid from the esophagus, narrowing of the lower esophagus was noted. The endoscope passed through with difficulty and resistance, reaching the cardia at 38 cm from the incisors. Following endotracheal intubation anesthesia, the endoscope was reinserted. Submucosal injection was performed at approximately 30 cm from the incisors, followed by longitudinal mucosal incision and tunnel creation to the gastric fundus. Approximately 1–2 cm distal to the tunnel opening, the circular muscle of the esophagus was incised using a Flush knife, extending to 2 cm below the cardia. Exposed blood vessels were coagulated with electrocautery forceps. The tunnel opening was closed with a closure clip.

data.diagnosis:
Esophageal space-occupying lesion; suspected carcinoma.  
Gastric body polyp.  
Chronic non-atrophic gastritis.  
Duodenal submucosal protrusion (suspected cyst).
data.full_findings:
Approximately 30 cm to 40 cm from the incisors, a mass-like lesion is observed in the esophagus, with surface ulceration and bleeding, covered by dirty exudate. The lesion involves three-fourths of the esophageal wall, causing severe luminal stenosis. A standard gastroscope could not pass through the narrowed segment, and a transnasal gastroscope was used to traverse the stenosis. The lesion extends to the cardia. Six biopsy specimens were taken from the lesion, which was soft and prone to bleeding.

Two Yamada type I polypoid lesions, each measuring approximately 0.5 cm × 0.5 cm, are seen in the gastric fundus, with reddened surface mucosa. The remaining gastric body mucosa shows congestion and edema. The gastric pool is clear, with no varices observed.

The gastric body mucosa is smooth, with clear folds and good peristalsis.

The gastric angulus mucosa is smooth, exhibiting a red and white appearance, predominantly red.

The gastric antrum mucosa is smooth, also showing a red and white appearance, predominantly red, with good peristalsis.

The pyloric mucosa is smooth, the pyloric orifice is round, and peristalsis is regular.

The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers.

A submucosal elevation is noted in the descending part of the duodenum, with smooth overlying mucosa and normal coloration. The biopsy forceps palpation reveals soft texture, positive cushion sign, and translucency. The remaining villous structure is normal.

data.diagnosis:
Lesion at the cardia ridge, pending pathology (suspected carcinoma).

data.full_findings:
The esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristaltic contractions. No distinct brownish areas are observed under NBI examination.  
The gastroesophageal junction is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardia.  
The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices.  
A raised lesion is observed at the cardia ridge, with a 0.3 cm × 0.4 cm A2-stage ulcer at the apex. The ulcer is roundish, with well-defined borders, converging folds, congested and edematous base, covered by thin exudate, and slightly rigid. The surrounding mucosa shows congestion and edema. Under NBI+ME examination, irregular microstructures are noted, with focal loss of microstructure, irregular microvessels, visible DL, and irregular WOS, but no WGA. Two biopsies were taken, showing firm texture and easy bleeding. Hemostasis was achieved with thrombin spray.  
In the upper lesser curvature of the gastric body, patchy mucosal roughness and redness are observed, with converging folds. Under NBI+ME examination, a brownish area is noted, with regular microstructures but irregular microvessels, and no WOS or WGA. One biopsy was taken, showing soft texture.  
The remaining gastric body mucosa shows congestion, edema, and regular folds.  
The gastric angulus mucosa is smooth, with a red and white appearance predominantly red, and RAC is visible.  
In the greater curvature of the gastric antrum, patchy mucosal roughness and redness are observed. Under NBI+ME examination, no distinct borders are noted, with irregular microvessels and microstructures, no WOS, visible WGA, and LBC. Two biopsies were taken, showing soft texture. The remaining antral mucosa shows congestion, edema, and a mottled red and white appearance, with good peristalsis.  
The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a round pyloric opening and regular peristalsis.  
The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers.  
The duodenal descending segment mucosa shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis:
Gastric antrum occupying lesion (suspected carcinoma)
Gastric retention
data.full_findings:
Food residue retention is observed in the esophagus. Despite repeated suction, some areas of the mucosa remain obscured, affecting visualization. The visible mucosa appears rough, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristaltic contractions.  

The gastroesophageal junction is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardia.  

Upon advancing the endoscope into the gastric cavity, a large amount of liquid and solid food residue is observed. Repeated suction yields unsatisfactory results, obscuring most of the mucosa in the gastric fundus and body, severely hindering visualization.  

The visible mucosa of the gastric body shows congestion and edema, with clear rugal folds and good peristalsis.  

The visible mucosa of the gastric angle exhibits congestion and edema, with a red and white mottled appearance predominantly red.  

An irregularly shaped lesion is observed in the gastric antrum, with ulceration on the surface covered by thick yellowish exudate. The surrounding mucosa shows irregular elevation and spontaneous bleeding. The lesion causes pyloric stenosis. To avoid aspiration, no further attempts were made to advance the endoscope for observation. Three biopsies were taken from the gastric antral lesion, which appeared friable and bled easily.

The gastroesophageal junction is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardia.  
The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices observed.  
The gastric body mucosa is smooth, with distinct folds and good peristalsis.  
The gastric angulus mucosa is smooth, showing a mottled appearance with alternating red and white patches.  
On the lesser curvature of the gastric antrum, the mucosa appears rough and erythematous, with a central depression measuring approximately 0.5 × 0.5 cm. One biopsy was taken, which was soft in texture. The remaining mucosa is smooth, showing a mottled appearance with alternating red and white patches, and peristalsis is good.  
The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a rounded pyloric orifice and regular peristalsis.  
The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers observed.  
The mucosa of the descending duodenum shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis: Heterotopic gastric mucosa in the esophagus; Gastric polypectomy; Chronic non-atrophic gastritis with verrucous elevations
data.full_findings:
Approximately 15 cm from the incisors, an island-like, round, orange-red ectopic mucosa is observed in the esophagus, with clear boundaries. The remaining esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristalsis.  

The cardia is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardia opening.  

The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices observed.  

A Yamada type I polyp, measuring approximately 0.3 cm × 0.3 cm, is seen on the greater curvature of the upper gastric body. The surface mucosa is smooth, and the polyp was removed with biopsy forceps and sent for pathological examination. The remaining gastric body mucosa is smooth, with regular folds and good peristalsis.  

The gastric angulus mucosa is smooth, with a red and white appearance, predominantly red.  

Scattered verrucous elevations with central depressions are observed in the gastric antrum. A biopsy was taken from the larger lesion, which was soft in texture. The remaining antral mucosa shows congestion and edema, with a red and white appearance, predominantly red, and good peristalsis.  

The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a round pyloric opening and regular peristalsis.  

The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers.  

The duodenal descending segment mucosa shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis:
1. Esophageal mucosal lesion pending pathology results.  
2. Chronic non-atrophic gastritis.
data.full_findings:
**Esophagus:**  
Under NBI observation, two brownish areas are noted at approximately 27 cm and 32 cm from the incisors. CLE (confocal laser endomicroscopy) findings: The squamous epithelium of the esophagus shows clear borders and regular morphology, with mild fluorescein sodium exudation. After iodine staining, lightly stained areas are observed, and the esophagus exhibits mild mottling. One biopsy specimen was taken from each site at approximately 27 cm and 32 cm from the incisors, both of soft consistency.

**Cardia:**  
Located at 40 cm from the incisors, the dentate line is clear, and the cardia opening contracts normally.

**Gastric Fundus:**  
The mucosa shows congestion and edema. The gastric pool is clear, with no varices observed.

**Gastric Body:**  
The mucosa shows congestion and edema. The gastric folds are clear, and peristalsis is normal.

**Gastric Angle:**  
The mucosa shows congestion and edema, with a red and white appearance, predominantly red.

**Gastric Antrum:**  
The mucosa shows congestion and edema, with a red and white appearance and mild mottling. CLE findings: The gastric glands are normal in number, size, and morphology, with elongated pits. The cellular morphology is normal. The blood vessels are normal in number and morphology, with mild fluorescein sodium exudation.

**Pylorus:**  
The mucosa shows congestion and edema. The pyloric opening is round, and peristalsis is regular.

**Duodenal Bulb:**  
The mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers observed.

**Descending Duodenum:**  
The mucosa shows no abnormalities.

The duodenal descending segment mucosa shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis: Magnifying endoscopy with marking for gastric angle lesion
data.full_findings: At the middle portion of the gastric angle, slightly toward the antral side, patchy erosions are observed. Under magnification with NBI, slight disorganization of the microvascular and microglandular structures is noted. The periphery of the lesion was marked using a dual knife. The endoscope was then withdrawn.

data.diagnosis:
1. Multiple white flat elevations in the esophagus  
2. Chronic atrophic gastritis (C1)
data.full_findings:
Scattered patchy white flat elevations are observed in the esophagus, with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. CLE examination reveals inconspicuous IPCL, with a small amount of squamous epithelium visible, showing relatively regular morphology (the patient's family declined pathological biopsy). The remaining esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristaltic contractions. NBI observation shows no obvious brownish areas.

The cardia is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardia.

The gastric fundus mucosa exhibits congestion and edema, with scattered punctate mucosal redness. The mucus lake is clear, and no varices are observed.

The gastric body mucosa shows congestion and edema, with scattered punctate mucosal redness. The folds are thickened, and peristalsis is normal.

The gastric angle mucosa displays congestion and edema, with a red-and-white appearance predominantly red.

The gastric antrum mucosa exhibits congestion and edema, with a red-and-white mottled appearance. Peristalsis is normal.

The pyloric mucosa shows congestion and edema, with the prepyloric area appearing rough and red. CLE: The glandular morphology is relatively regular, with localized epithelial cells showing black goblet cells and significant fluorescein sodium exudation (the patient's family declined pathological biopsy). The pyloric orifice is deformed and remains persistently open.

The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers observed.

The duodenal descending segment mucosa shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis: Based on the history, post-treatment for gastric lymphoma.
data.full_findings:
The esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristalsis. No tea-colored areas are observed under OE staining.  
The cardia is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardia.

The gastric body mucosa exhibits congestion and edema, with distinct folds and good peristalsis.

The gastric antrum presents a circumferential irregular elevated lesion, causing gastric lumen narrowing and pseudopylorus formation. An ulcer measuring approximately 1.0–0.8 cm is observed on the lesser curvature, covered with yellow thick exudate, with rigid folds and loss of the gastric angle. Three biopsies were taken from the ulcer periphery, showing firm texture. The remaining antral mucosa shows congestion and edema, with a red and white appearance predominantly red, and good peristalsis.  
The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a round pyloric opening and regular peristalsis.  
The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, without ulcers.  
The descending duodenal mucosa shows no abnormalities.

data.full_findings:
At 32 cm from the incisors, the esophageal mucosa appears locally rough with a yellowish-white discoloration. The apex shows erosion and an orange-red hue. One biopsy specimen was taken. The remaining mucosa is smooth, with clearly visible submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristaltic contractions. No distinct brownish areas were observed under NBI examination.

At 35 cm from the incisors, the gastroesophageal junction shows a clear Z-line. At the 9 o'clock position below the Z-line, a 0.4 cm diameter ulcer is present, covered with thin white exudate. Two biopsy specimens were taken, which were soft in texture. At the 12 o'clock position, the mucosa appears rough and erythematous. Four biopsy specimens were taken, which were soft in texture. The contraction of the gastroesophageal junction is normal.

The duodenal bulb mucosa shows congestion and edema, with no ulceration observed.

The mucosa of the descending duodenum appears normal.

Gastric polypectomy
data.full_findings:
The esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular markings and normal peristaltic contractions. No obvious tea-colored areas were observed under OE.  
The cardia is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardial orifice.  
The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices observed.  
A single Yamada type I polyp, approximately 0.2 cm × 0.2 cm in size, was observed on the greater curvature of the upper gastric body. The surface mucosa was smooth and matched the color of the surrounding mucosa. It was removed with biopsy forceps. The remaining gastric body mucosa is smooth, with regular folds and good peristalsis.  
The gastric angulus mucosa shows congestion and edema, with a mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas.  
On the lesser curvature of the gastric antrum, patchy mucosa appears rough and erythematous. One biopsy was taken, showing soft texture. On the greater curvature of the gastric antrum, scattered verrucous elevations with depressed and erythematous apices were observed. One biopsy was taken, showing soft texture. The remaining antral mucosa shows congestion and edema, with a mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas, and good peristalsis.  
The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a rounded pyloric orifice and regular peristalsis.  
The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers observed.  
The mucosa of the descending duodenum shows no abnormalities.

data.diagnosis:
Chronic atrophic gastritis (C-2); Gastric xanthoma;  
Gastric body lesion pending pathology; Duodenal bulbitis
data.full_findings:
The esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristaltic contractions. No distinct brownish areas are observed under OE staining.  
The cardia is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardial orifice.  
The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices observed.  
A raised lesion is noted on the posterior wall of the mid-gastric body, measuring approximately 3.0 cm × 2.0 cm, with a rough and erythematous mucosal surface. Three biopsies were taken, showing firm texture. The remaining gastric body mucosa is smooth, with clear folds and good peristalsis.  
The gastric angulus mucosa shows congestion and edema, with a mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas.  
A yellowish granular elevation is observed in the gastric antrum. The remaining antral mucosa exhibits congestion and edema, with a mottled appearance of alternating red and white areas, and good peristalsis.  
The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a rounded pyloric orifice and regular peristalsis.  
The duodenal bulb mucosa shows congestion and edema, with no ulcers.  
The mucosa of the descending duodenum appears normal.

data.diagnosis: Hiatal hernia    Chronic non-atrophic gastritis

The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices observed.  
The gastric body mucosa is smooth, with distinct rugal folds and good peristalsis.

data.diagnosis:
Heterotopic gastric mucosa in the esophagus  
Reflux esophagitis (LA-A)  
Chronic non-atrophic gastritis
data.full_findings:
One island-like, round, orange-red ectopic mucosa is observed in the upper esophagus. A mucosal defect, approximately 1 mm in maximum diameter, is noted above the cardia in the lower esophagus, with no evidence of fusion. The remaining esophageal mucosa is smooth, with clear submucosal vascular patterns and normal peristaltic contractions.  

The cardia is located 40 cm from the incisors, with a clear dentate line and normal contraction of the cardial orifice.  

The gastric fundus mucosa is smooth, with clear mucus lake and no varices.  

The gastric body mucosa shows congestion and edema, with distinct folds and good peristalsis.  

The gastric angle mucosa exhibits congestion and edema, appearing red and white with a predominance of redness.  

The gastric antrum mucosa shows congestion and edema, appearing red and white with a predominance of redness, and demonstrates good peristalsis.  

The pyloric mucosa is smooth, with a rounded pyloric orifice and regular peristalsis.  

The duodenal bulb mucosa is smooth, with no ulcers.  

The descending duodenal mucosa shows no abnormalities.
